messageBody:
perhaps... but I some how think it is overrated. These are all
assumptions (good ones, most likely). Has anyone had real-world
experience with this? I am not trying to be a skeptic just for
skepticism's sake. I want to be convinced.

-jason
-----Original Message-----
From: Eric Vought [mailto:evought@...]
Sent: Monday, November 12, 2001 9:56 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] RE: Separate Package for Test Cases or not ?


Also, even if the unit tests are not complete or perfect, they provide
an
example of how the programmer thought the API was supposed to work-
beyond
what is covered in the documentation. By looking at their test code and
comparing it to your code (which maybe isn't working), you can get an
idea
where you or the vendor are making unwarranted assumptions.

On Mon, 12 Nov 2001, David Stagner wrote:

> "Rogers, Jason" wrote:
> >
> > "David Stagner" wrote:
> > > Unit tests document API usage very well, for starters. And they
> > suggest
> > > where any bugs encountered might be, even by their absence (a
> > > problematic condition may not be tested, and a set of tests
could
> > rule
> > > out a bunch of possible causes for a bug).
> > >
> >
> > This seems like a pretty weak argument to me. They only document
the
> > set of
> > the API that the authors chose to test, and they only test to the
> > authors'
> > degrees of comfortability. Truth be known, just because JUnit is in
use
> > does
> > not mean that the code is being tested thoroughly. Right? You may
be
> > right
> > that it could show you what isn't tested, but not necessarily why.
And
> > it only
> > gives you a clue as to what is not tested and what is. There may
not be
> > a one
> > to one mapping of the public API to the tests.
>
> Granted. I was assuming that the set of unit tests theoretically
> provided by our imaginary vendor (has anyone ever seen a non-open
source
> vendor do this?) would be reasonably thorough, complete, and
> representative. If the unit tests don't exercise all the documented
> methods and boundaries of the API, they're incomplete anyway. The
hard
> part comes with testing coupling, interaction, and state changes
between
> components, where the non-trivial bugs often lurk.
>
> On a more philosophical level, i'd suggest that most unit testing is
> either very useful, or mostly useless, depending on the confidence of
> the programmer in the testing process. Cowardly testing is a sign of
a
> lack of confidence in the code. Once a programmer gets in the habit
of
> serious unit testing, the programmer will almost always be more
> confident in the code - and thus more likely to test thoroughly. Good
> unit testing is a self-reinforcing feedback loop. And if i were given
a
> set of unit tests from a vendor that clearly did not thoroughly test
the
> public interface of the software, i would immediately distrust the
> software in question.
>
